para.paratext: A necessity exception to the hearsay rule was established in former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-1(b),[1] which allowed for the admission of hearsay evidence “in specified cases from necessity.” This was interpreted to allow the admission of statements when (1) the declarant is unavailable to testify at trial, (2) the declarant's out-of-court statement is relevant to a material fact and more probative on that fact than other available evidence, and (3) the statement shows particular guarantees of trustworthiness.[2] The specific indicia of reliability or trustworthiness need not have been established by the testifying witness alone.[3] The requirement of “particularized guarantees of trustworthiness” was satisfied when the declaration is coupled with circumstances which attributed verity to the declaration.[4] However, the Georgia Supreme Court does caution that the residual exception is designed to be used very rarely and only in exceptional circumstances.[5]

Georgia's and the federal necessity exceptions to the hearsay rule had been very similar, but, with Georgia's adoption of the notice requirement in O.C.G.A. § 24-8-807, they are now identical. Although the statute no longer uses the term “necessity,” the principle remains intact. The residual exception, though, was designed to be used “very rarely, and only in exceptional circumstances,” when certain exceptional guarantees of trustworthiness exist and when high degrees of probativeness and necessity are present.[6] Trustworthiness is assessed under the totality of circumstances, including any motives the declarant may have had to be untruthful in making the statement and the extent to which the declarant enjoyed a relationship of confidence with the witness.[7]
O.C.G.A. § 24-8-807 states the following:
A statement not specifically covered by any law but having equivalent circumstantial guarantees of trustworthiness shall not be excluded by the hearsay rule, if the court determines that:
The statement is offered as evidence of a material fact;
The statement is more probative on the point for which it is offered than any other evidence which the proponent can procure through reasonable efforts; and
The general purposes of the rules of evidence and the interests of justice will best be served by admission of the statement into evidence.

However, a statement may not be admitted under this Code section unless the proponent of it makes known to the adverse party, sufficiently in advance of the trial or hearing to provide the adverse party with a fair opportunity to prepare to meet it, the proponent's intention to offer the statement and the particulars of it, including the name and address of the declarant.

From an early date, the Georgia Supreme Court recognized the need for a broader hearsay rule in certain cases. In Hines v. Donaldson,[8] the court approved the admission of certain hearsay statements which did not fit a usual exception, but did not go so far as to establish a new rule.

In Moore v. Atlanta Transit System, Inc., the Court of Appeals approved the admission of a declaration of the deceased injured party in an action for damages where there was no other witness to the alleged occurrence. In his opinion in that case, Judge Eberhardt exhaustively explored the Georgia law on the necessity exception up to 1961.[9] Moore did not address the trustworthiness of the declaration.

Necessity alone is not enough to render a declaration admissible. In Chrysler Motors Corp. v. Davis,[10] the Georgia Supreme Court clarified that the “principal ingredient” in determining the admissibility of a declaration under the necessity exception is the “trustworthiness” of the declaration itself.

In Chapel v. State,[11] the court subsequently added the requirements that the statement be relevant to a material fact and that it be more probative on that material fact than other evidence that may be procured and offered. “These requirements were borrowed from the ‘catch-all’ hearsay exception in Fed. R. Evid. 807 and similar state rules of evidence, because ‘death or unavailability of the declarant cannot alone satisfy the necessity component without allowing the exception to swallow the rule.’”[12]

Current practice therefore allows for the admission of hearsay evidence only when (1) the declarant is unavailable to testify at trial, (2) the declarant's out-of-court statement is relevant to a material fact and more probative on that fact than other available evidence, and (3) the statement shows particular guarantees of trustworthiness.[13]

Whether a hearsay statement is sufficiently trustworthy to be admitted under the necessity exception is a matter within the discretion of the trial court, and its admissibility will be determined by the circumstances surrounding each statement. The Georgia Supreme Court has said that a statement is sufficiently trustworthy if “the declarant's truthfulness is so clear from the surrounding circumstances that the test of cross-examination would be of marginal utility.”[14]

However, “[t]he specific indicia of reliability need not be established by the testifying witness alone.”[15] The requirement of particularized guarantees of trustworthiness is satisfied when the declaration is coupled with circumstances which attribute verity to the declaration.[16] Thus, where the witnesses are close friends of the declarant, and are privy to confidences regarding domestic violence issues, they bear the necessary standard of reliability expected under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-807.[17] Likewise, statements made to very close personal friends, when made because of fear or apprehension, also bear the necessary standard of reliability.[18]

In Buttram v. State,[19] the court held that out-of-court statements made by a murder victim to her father were sufficiently trustworthy because the statements were made by the victim while confiding in her father. Likewise, in Miller v State,[20] the Georgia Supreme Court found a declarant's statement to a friend of 30 years regarding an incidence of domestic violence highly credible.

In Holton v. State,[21] however, the out-of-court statements of the defendant's brother made to the defendant's husband did not have a sufficient guarantee of trustworthiness because the brother had only known the husband for a few months, there was no evidence that the brother was confiding in the husband, and there were conflicting versions of the events surrounding the statement.

In Holmes v. State,[22] the Georgia Supreme Court held that statements of a witness, subsequently unavailable, were sufficiently trustworthy when “made in the course of an official investigation, before either had an opportunity to consult with any other witness.”

In McCulley v. State,[23] the court stated that the following factors are also probative of reliability: “(1) consistency of the statements; (2) lack of a motive to fabricate; (3) the nature of the statements; (4) the relationship between the declarant and the accused; and (5) whether the statement was based upon a faulty recollection or observation.”

The Supreme Court questioned its holding in Holmes in Yancey v. State[24] by admitting, “We have struggled with what weight to give the ‘official investigation’ factor.” The court then suggested that an out-of-court statement is “not trustworthy, as a matter of law, simply because it was told to police officers during an official investigation. Instead, [such statements] must be reviewed in light of the surrounding circumstances on a case-by-case basis. Among the relevant factors to consider are whether the declarant had a motive to lie, the spontaneity of the statement, and the consistent repetition of the statement.”[25]

As a general rule, a trial court does not abuse its discretion when it admits, under the necessity exception to the hearsay rule, hearsay testimony consisting of uncontradicted statements made by an unavailable witness to individuals in whom the declarant placed great confidence and to whom the declarant turned for help with problems.[26]

Death is the most obvious example of unavailability, but it is not the only situation in which the necessity exception may be invoked In Holmes,[27] supra, a plurality of the Georgia Supreme Court reasoned that, in light of the other safeguards limiting the admissibility of declarations under the exception, “there is clearly no need, if there ever was, to restrict the meaning of ‘unavailability’ to instances of death, privilege, and deliberate hiding, as urged by [some].” In Holmes, the court concluded that a witness is sufficiently unavailable for purposes of invoking the necessity exception if the state exercised due diligence in attempting to secure the witness's presence at trial but had been unable to locate the witness.[28]

When offering a declaration under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-807, a party must show that admission of the declaration is actually “necessary.” Unavailability, in and of itself, does not satisfy the “necessary” component. As noted above, in Chapel v. State,[29] the Supreme Court imposed the requirement that the proponent of such evidence establish that the declaration be both relevant to a material fact and actually more probative on that material fact than other evidence that may be procured and offered. Thus, where hearsay evidence is merely cumulative or even just less probative of other evidence available at trial, the declaration may not be admitted under the necessity exception.[30]

Such was the case in Willis v. State[31] where the state presented testimony from two witnesses who had personally observed the defendant throw a radio at his girlfriend, punch her in face, throw her against brick wall, and threaten to kill her. The court of appeals held that the girlfriend's hearsay statements to friends regarding the abuse and threats by the defendant were not properly admitted into evidence under the necessity exception because they were no more probative than the direct evidence of prior abuse.

Murder victim's out-of-court statements were admissible under the necessity exception to the hearsay rule where the victim was dead, the victim made the statements to his father and brother, in whom he confided and trusted, and the statements were probative on the issues of motive and intent. Jackson v. State, 284 Ga. 826, 672 S.E.2d 640 (2009).

Prior statement of a murder victim in which the victim described arguments he had with the defendant were admissible under the necessity exception to the hearsay rule where the statements were made to life-long friend with whom he placed great confidence. The statement constituted some of the most probative evidence regarding the difficulty between the victim and the defendant. Character v. State, 285 Ga. 112, 674 S.E.2d 280 (2009).

Testimony of the victim's confidants about prior difficulties between the defendant and the victim had sufficient guarantees of trustworthiness to be admissible under the necessity exception to the hearsay rule where each confidant had known the victim for several years, had spoken with the victim on a regular basis, and had known about the victim's relationship with the defendant, as well as other personal matters. Matthews v. State, 284 Ga. 819, 672 S.E.2d 633 (2009).

Statements by victim to a neighbor before victim was taken to a hospital were admissible under the necessity exception to the hearsay rule because: victim placed great confidence in the neighbor and turned to him for help with problems, victim was related to the neighbor's wife by marriage, victim and the neighbor saw each other every day, victim would bring his mail to the neighbor for it to be read to him, and victim's statements were, in effect, immediate outcries to a neighbor for help. Treadwell v. State, 285 Ga. 736, 684 S.E.2d 244 (2009) (overruled on other grounds by, Clay v. State, 290 Ga. 822, 725 S.E.2d 260 (2012)).

Evidence that witnesses were friends of the victims and reported the utterances to police shortly after the victims were killed was insufficient to authorize the admission of such hearsay testimony under the necessity exception because there was no showing of the required special relationship between the deceased declarants and the proffered witnesses. Coleman v. State, 286 Ga. 291, 687 S.E.2d 427 (2009).
Holmes v. State, 271 Ga. 138, 516 S.E.2d 61(1999). See also Cook v. State, 273 Ga. 574, 543 S.E.2d 701 (2001) (reaching a similar conclusion).
